key_points: The ACLU supports the impeachment of President Trump, arguing it doesn't conflict with First Amendment rights.
The ACLU board unanimously passed a resolution calling for Trump's impeachment, emphasizing his effort to subvert election results.
They argue Trump's actions, including his speech on Jan. 6, are part of a pattern of behavior that justifies impeachment.
Impeachment is seen as a political remedy, not a criminal proceeding, aimed at removing an executive official for abuse of office.
The First Amendment does not protect public employees, including the president, from sanctions related to speech in their official capacity.
Impeachment does not require conviction of a crime but a determination of abuse of office warranting removal.
The ACLU has a long history of defending free speech rights, regardless of the popularity of the speech.
Brandenburg v. Ohio is cited as a landmark Supreme Court case establishing First Amendment protections but does not obstruct impeachment.
The article suggests Trump's legacy may include sparking a resistance movement focused on social justice and constitutional norms.
The author believes society is grappling with complex issues of race, rights, and freedoms, leading to beneficial debates.
